title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
A top investor at the world's largest hedge fund says he does not expect a repeat of the “Great Inflation” of the 1970s.

Bob Prince, who runs Bridgewater Associates with Ray Dalio and Greg Jensen, told the Financial Times that long-running deflationary forces would eventually curtail recent price rises and that while “you are going to get some inflation”, it would be “moderate”.

His comments come amid a furious debate on Wall Street over whether a buzzing economic recovery, a flood of fiscal and monetary stimulus and supply chain problems would cause a lasting surge in prices for goods and services.

John Williams, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, yesterday made some of his most bullish comments since the start of the pandemic but insisted the US economy was not ready for the central bank to start pulling back its hefty support.

The comments from Williams came on the eve of an appearance by Jay Powell in Congress. In prepared remarks released yesterday, the Federal Reserve chair pointed to the “sustained improvement” in the economy but highlighted the uneven pace of the recovery.

Senior Democratic lawmaker Carolyn Maloney warned the Fed against putting on the brakes “too quickly”, in an interview with the Financial Times before Powell's appearance.

Five stories in the news

1. EU opens probe against Google's advertising technology The European Commission has opened a formal antitrust probe against Google to examine whether the US group has broken EU rules by giving an advantage to its own online display ad technology services, to the detriment of rivals. 

  • In other technology news, Facebook's first advertising partner in its Oculus virtual reality headset has pulled out of the initiative less than a week after the tie-up was announced, following a backlash from the gaming community.

2. FDA accused of cozy ties with Big Pharma The US Food and Drug Administration's approval of aducanumab, a contentious Alzheimer's drug made by Biogen, has led to calls for acting commissioner Janet Woodcock to be removed amid criticism that the medicines regulator is too close to Big Pharma.

3. Student athletes win US Supreme Court showdown against NCAA The US Supreme Court yesterday sided with student athletes who brought an antitrust challenge against the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The blockbuster ruling could reshape the country's more than $14bn college sports industry.

4. Soho House files for New York IPO The owner of private members' clubs in North America, Europe and Asia, has outlined aggressive plans for expansion as it filed to go public in New York. The group is to be renamed Membership Collective Group as part of the initial public offering which is targeting a $3bn valuation, according to people familiar with the matter.

5. Hong Kong's Apple Daily at risk of closure The pro-democracy tabloid is on the verge of closure after its assets were frozen by the government last week, restricting its ability to operate. The asset freeze follows the arrest of two of the newspaper's senior executives and the imprisonment of founder Jimmy Lai.

Coronavirus digest

  • The closure of a container shipping terminal in Shenzhen, China in late May after port workers tested positive for Covid-19, is leading to strains on the global supply chain.

  • Eurozone consumers are flocking back to bars and restaurants, booking holidays and travelling to work, according to high-frequency data. But in Greece, lockdowns have delayed the tourist season and deterred workers, threatening the economic recovery.

  • Colombia has recorded its worst day yet for deaths from Covid-19, pushing the total number of fatalities since the pandemic began to more than 100,000.

Follow our live coronavirus blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter.

The day ahead

NYC mayoral primary In heavily Democratic New York City, the winner of today's primary will carry November's election. Eric Adams, a black former policeman who has called for more NYPD officers, is one of the frontrunners in a crowded contest that has become a referendum on New Yorkers' attitudes towards policing and public security.

Catalan separatist pardons Spain's leftwing government is to issue pardons for nine jailed Catalan separatists today, which it says will pave the way for reconciliation but the opposition argues undermines the rule of law.

What else we're reading and listening to

Bermuda digs in against global tax The island tax haven's political and business elite are responding to a G7 push for a minimum corporate income tax as they would the approach of an Atlantic hurricane, in hopes of keeping intact a 19th-century revenue regime that leaves company profits untouched.

How China broke the Asian model While the economics of the China model are derivative, the politics are new, writes Gideon Rachman. Unlike Taiwan or South Korea, which turned from one-party states to democracies as they got richer, China under Xi has entrenched the dominance of the Communist party.

Will boredom kill Instagram? The photo-sharing app, once the apple of Facebook's eye, has spent years rebuffing accusations of toxicity. But tedium poses a painful new threat to Instagram's moneymaking ability just as its owner's market valuation approaches $1tn, writes Elaine Moore.

Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee: ‘Ours is a social science' The Nobel laureates call for better economic “plumbing” after the pandemic and warn about inaction over climate change. This is the latest in our Economists Exchange series featuring conversations between top FT commentators and leading economists about the economic recovery after coronavirus.

Tech Tonic podcast: The game-changer The podcast that investigates our new technological age returns with a new series exploring the promise and pitfalls of artificial intelligence. We speak to experts in the field, including Demis Hassabis, chief executive of Google's DeepMind. 

  • Go deeper John Thornhill, innovation editor, talks to the FT's Daily News Briefing podcast about the new series and some of the surprising discoveries it made.

Life & Arts

Summer books of 2021 Today it is the turn of chief economics commentator Martin Wolf to share his favourite books of the year. There is also an appreciation of the best audio books, and restaurant critic Tim Hayward shares his favourite titles on food and drink. You can share your favourite reads of the year here. The best responses will be published on FT.com.
